awd_titl_txt: The Learner Data Institute: Harnessing The Data Revolution To Make The Learning Ecosystem More Effective, Efficient, and Engaging
awd_abstract_narration:
The project will lay the foundation for a Learner Data Institute, to further understanding of how people learn, how to improve adaptive instructional systems, and how to create learning systems that are more effective, efficient, engaging, and affordable.  An interdisciplinary team of people from academia, industry, and government will work together to improve the effectiveness of the learning ecosystem for the benefit of its hundreds of thousands of students, prepare teachers for the future learning ecosystem, and contribute to accelerating discovery and transforming the education ecosystem through the use of big data and cloud computing. The project will impact a number of communities including learning sciences, data science, artificial intelligence in education, assessment, educational data mining, and machine learning. The outcomes will be widely disseminated through training materials, workshops, tutorials, and a course for researchers and practitioners. 

The two-year conceptualization phase of the Learner Data Institute will focus on building a strong community of researchers, define research priorities, and develop interdisciplinary prototype solutions that address critical student learning, cyber-learning, and learning engineering challenges. Based on modern theories of learning and recent advances in educational technologies, artificial intelligence, sensing technologies, signal processing, and data science, the team will explore new frontiers in multi-faceted (cognitive, motivational, emotional, etc.) learner data collection, analysis, and visualization in order to understand and possibly transform how learners learn with technology.  The multi-disciplinary team will address core research questions such as: (1) how to transform a widely distributed group of interdisciplinary researchers, developers, and practitioners into a community of practice that can fully exploit the data revolution for the benefit of the learners and educational stakeholders; (2) how adaptive instructional systems (AISs) and data science can be used as a research vehicle to further understanding of how learners learn; (3) how the human-technology partnership with data and data science can be used to improve learners? and teachers? ability to employ technology in ways that facilitate learning and improve the effectiveness, scalability, and affordability of AISs in order to maximize the potential of learning ecologies of the future; and (5) more generally, how to extend the frontiers of data science to include: new methods of data collection and design; more interpretable, knowledge-rich machine learning methods (e.g., by combining Deep Learning with Markov Logic); scalable new inference and learning algorithms symmetries and joint dependencies in the data; and methods for identifying causal mechanisms from unstructured, semi-structured, and structured data. While the project will address core educational tasks in the context of online and blended learning environments, the proposed data science methods and models are generally applicable to other instructional contexts as well as other science and engineering areas. All models, software, processes, and data used in the project will be documented and disseminated for everyone to use and build on the outcomes of the project.

This project is part of the National Science Foundation's Harnessing the Data Revolution Big Idea activity.  The effort is jointly funded by the Directorate for Education and Human Resources.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The Learner Data Institute project designed, implemented, tested, and refined a framework for a Data Science institute fousing on harnessing the data revolution to make the learning ecosystem more effective, engaging, equitable, efficient, and affordable. The framework was based on a team structure and collaboration activities and processes that facilitates effective science convergence and efficient team operations.

The team structure consisted of a core team that served a coordination and monitoring function, expert panels which provided a solid perspective from a particular domain by grouping together experts in one particular area such as Data Science or Learning Science, and mutual interest-groups which share an interest such as language and discourse in education.

The team setup processes and activities designed to facilitate input from various domains as well as to encourage cross-domain collaboration and solutions that account for input from various areas of expertise. Brainstorming sessions were run to identify challenges and opportunities at the intersection of Data Science and education/learning. Another activity was a series of sessions on identifying transformative apps, i.e., broad and acute needs in education which if addressed will transform the learning ecosystem. The goal of identifying such transformative apps was to encourage the identification of areas of investment that could have the broadest, most transformative impact if addressed and then identifiy how data and Data Science can facilitate the development of solution to enable such tranformative apps in education. Brainstorming within and across expertise coupled with other collaboration processes such as Nominal Group Technique (NGT), pre-mortem analysis, and SWOT analysis proved to be effective and efficient ways to coordinate all our team's resources in terms of time and expertise to serve the goals of the Learner Data Institute whose mission was to transform the learning ecosystem through harnessing the data revolution. Another pocess for cross-disciplinary collaboration and science convergence was designed for the solution prototyping activity. Solution prototyping involved one or two senior personnel proposing a specific task they were interested in leading. Examples of specific task are variational autoencoder based student assessment, domain modelling across domains, scaling up domain modelling methods using cloud computing, transfer (machine) learning for freely-generated student responsesm, and utomated discovery of learner strategies using neuro-symbolic approaches.

The project identified the following key investment opportunity areas or thrusts for Phase 2 (institute phase):

  • Challenge/Opportunity Area 1: Scaling Up Access To Learning Data – From Impoverished Datasets To Learning Data Convergence To Comprehensive Learner Models
  • Challenge/Opportunity Area 2: Novel, Richer, More Powerful, Scalable, and Accurate Data-intensive Solutions to Core Education Tasks
  • Challenge/Opportunity Area 3: Human Technology Frontier – Pushing For Wider Adoption and Integration Of AISs

The opportunities were pursued as a whole team and also as smaller groups resulting in additional funding. Indeed, the project trained graduate students and researchers at early stage of their career which resulted in those faculty securing their own research funding. It should be noted that many of the graduate students and young researchers are from underrepresented groups in Data Science and other STEM disciplines. Key results and products, e.g., software and datasets, from the project were widely disseminated through peer-reviewed publications, presentations at major conference, the website, and other channels such as youtube videos and social media. Much of the project work has had impact on many learners of various backgrounds thus leading to broad impacts of the performed work.

In sum, the project furthered our understanding of how learners learn and developed advanced tools such as improved components of adaptive instructional systems, learning and learner-related datasets, teacher - adaptive instructional system partnership models, and infrastructure for transforming the learning ecosystem. Furthermore, the project developed more accurate, robust, and fine-grained assessment methods based on science convergence and large and diverse datasets offered by our corporate partners.
